extraction_notes: Unit 1 is introductory - covers concepts and tool overview, not specific trade setups. Strategy-specific knowledge will come from Units 6-15.

concepts.name: Footprint Tool
concepts.definition: A trading tool that captures all actual activity at each price, showing the physical interaction between buyers and sellers over a number of prices. Publicly available since 2003, widely adopted since 2016-2017.
examples: Shows volume traded at each price within a rotation

concepts.name: Delta
concepts.definition: The net difference between buying volume and selling volume at a specific price. Positive delta = more buying, negative delta = more selling. Represents the order flow at each price.
examples: If sellers sold 500 and buyers bought 96 at a price, delta = -404

concepts.name: Cumulative Delta
concepts.definition: The total delta accumulated over a series of rotations or time period. Shows the cumulative order flow - whether buyers or sellers have traded more volume overall.
examples: Net cumulative delta of -820 means more selling than buying across all price points in the rotation

concepts.name: Order Flow
concepts.definition: The interaction between buyers and sellers at each price level. Shown by the delta - who has ultimately traded more volume, the buyer or the seller.

concepts.name: Color Shading
concepts.definition: Visual representation in footprint showing relative delta intensity within a rotation. Uses three shades of blue (buying dominant) and three shades of red (selling dominant) - light, medium, and dark shades indicate relative strength.
examples: Dark red = high negative delta (strong selling), dark blue = high positive delta (strong buying)

concepts.name: Rotation
concepts.definition: A single bar/candle on the footprint chart. Can be time-based (fixed time interval) or point-and-figure based (fixed price movement).
examples: Time-based: 5-minute rotation. Point-and-figure: new rotation every 7 price levels

concepts.name: Point-and-Figure Rotation
concepts.definition: A rotation type where a new bar is created when the market moves a certain number of prices in one direction (e.g., 7 prices up or down). Time varies between rotations.

concepts.name: Time-Based Rotation
concepts.definition: A rotation type where a new bar is created at fixed time intervals (e.g., every 5 minutes). Standard candlestick timing approach.

concepts.name: Total Volume
concepts.definition: The total number of contracts traded within a rotation. Useful for identifying relative changes in activity between rotations.
examples: Going from 11,721 contracts to 4,752 contracts shows a massive relative drop-off in volume

concepts.name: Leading Information
concepts.definition: Real-time market data that hasn't yet been absorbed by the market. Footprint and price ladder provide leading information. Enables faster decision-making but requires specific strategies.

concepts.name: Lagging Information
concepts.definition: Historical market data that the market has already absorbed and acted upon. Candlesticks and market profile provide lagging information. Useful for context and pattern recognition.

concepts.name: Market Profile
concepts.definition: A lagging trading tool focused on shape and pattern recognition. Shows price, time, and volume but can be subjective. Used primarily for market context.

concepts.name: Price Ladder (DOM)
concepts.definition: A leading trading tool showing the order book. Fast-moving, shows pending orders but can include spoofing/fake orders. Useful for scalping strategies.

principles.name: Simplicity Principle
principles.statement: The trader who approaches the market with the most simplistic approach will have the greatest outcomes.
principles.implication: Keep strategies simple for more effective results
principles.rationale: Complexity introduces more failure points and decision fatigue

principles.name: Tool vs Strategy Distinction
principles.statement: A trading tool is not a trade strategy. A tool summarizes information; you use that summary to make strategy-based decisions.
principles.implication: Don't let the tool make decisions; use it to inform your predefined strategy
principles.rationale: Tools provide data, strategies provide decision logic

principles.name: Fact-Based Trading
principles.statement: Rather than taking a biased or opinionated subjective approach, learn to become very objective, drawing upon fact-based information within the market.
principles.implication: Base decisions on observable market data (delta, volume, order flow) not opinions
principles.rationale: Objective data removes emotional bias and is codifiable for automation

principles.name: Cross-Pollination of Tools
principles.statement: It's not about one tool being superior to the other, but about having a cross-pollination between tools and utilizing them where they can be most effective.
principles.condition: When selecting trading tools for a strategy
principles.implication: Use market profile for context, footprint/ladder for execution timing
principles.rationale: Different tools have different strengths (lagging vs leading information)

principles.name: Footprint Shows Only Actual Transactions
principles.statement: The footprint only shows exactly what is being transacted, unlike the price ladder which can show spoofing and fake orders.
principles.implication: Footprint data is more reliable for detecting genuine buying/selling pressure
principles.rationale: Eliminates noise from fake orders that never execute

procedures.name: Trade Strategy Learning Process Loop
procedures.purpose: Develop a consistent, routine approach to analyzing and templating markets for each strategy
steps: 1. OBSERVE: Learn characteristics that indicate when a trade strategy could be in play (timeframe, participants, market conditions)
2. IDENTIFY: Learn to recognize when that trade strategy is actively in play
3. EXECUTE: Apply the strategy based on identification
4. TEMPLATE: Document and systematize the strategy for consistent application
prerequisites: Complete theoretical understanding of the strategy

procedures.name: Drill-Based Learning Process
procedures.purpose: Reinforce strategy learning through active practice before seeing solutions
steps: 2. Attempt Drill 1 on your own (mentor on mute) - try to apply the strategy
3. Review Drill 2 with mentor guidance to see proper methodology
4. Compare your approach with the mentor's execution

procedures.name: Course Progression Path
procedures.purpose: Structure for learning footprint trading from theory to execution
steps: 1. Units 1-5: Learn theoretical principles and methodologies
2. Units 6-11: Footprint standalone strategies (footprint only required)
4. Unit 16: Bonus material - debriefing and developing own strategies

gotchas.name: Information Overload
gotchas.description: The footprint tool shows every single contract being transacted, which can feel overwhelming. Too much information can paralyze decision-making.
gotchas.trigger_condition: When first learning to use the footprint tool
gotchas.mitigation: Start with simplified views, focus on color shading for quick pattern recognition, gradually add complexity

gotchas.name: Tool-Driven Decision Making
gotchas.description: Falling into the trap of letting the trading tool make decisions rather than using it to inform a predefined strategy.
gotchas.trigger_condition: When relying too heavily on tool signals without a clear strategy
gotchas.mitigation: Always have a specific strategy; use the tool only to summarize information for that strategy's decision criteria

gotchas.name: Rushing Through Fundamentals
gotchas.description: Temptation to skip theoretical principles and jump straight to strategies. Without understanding principles, you cannot develop your own strategies.
gotchas.mitigation: Take time to learn principles first; they enable independent strategy development

gotchas.name: Price Ladder Spoofing
gotchas.description: The price ladder can show spoofing and fake orders that never execute, giving false signals about market intent.
gotchas.trigger_condition: When using price ladder for order flow analysis
gotchas.mitigation: Use footprint to confirm actual transactions vs pending orders

market_contexts.name: Momentum/Flow Strategy Context
market_contexts.description: Market conditions where momentum-based or flow-based strategies are most effective
market_contexts.chart_recommendation: Point-and-figure rotations better reveal these strategies

market_contexts.name: Counter-Trend/Relative Change Context
market_contexts.description: Market conditions where counter-trend and relative change strategies are most effective
detection: Relative shifts in volume between rotations
market_contexts.chart_recommendation: Time-based rotations better reveal these strategies

summary.unit_focus: Introduction to Footprint tool - concepts, philosophy, and tool comparison
summary.key_insight: Footprint provides objective, fact-based information showing actual transactions (unlike price ladder spoofing). Best used as a leading information tool combined with market profile for context.
summary.automation_relevance: High - concepts like delta, cumulative delta, color shading, and relative volume changes are all quantifiable and programmatically detectable. The emphasis on objective, fact-based decisions aligns well with algorithmic trading.
summary.missing_for_automation: Specific trade setups, entry/exit criteria, and risk parameters - these come in Units 6-15
